Comment: ‚Äú¬†America‚Äôs bush era global reputation was strong enough that our allies literally joined us in the Middle East with almost no questions asked‚Äù  This is accurate for countries like Canada who had little interest in this fight besides their friendship with the US. But in¬†all fairness, these were coalition wars in part because 9/11 terrified the fuck out of former colonial powers who were worried they could be next because they were *doing the same sketchy shit* in the Middle East that drew the terrorists‚Äô ire toward the US. There was definitely motivation to send a message: ‚ÄúThis is the kind of hell you can expect to rain down on you if try 9/11 in London or Paris.‚Äù (And indeed, London and Paris were the next targets.)  I just find it odd that this narrative of ‚Äúthe world used to love the US so much they followed them into the Middle East‚Äù keeps cropping up recently. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs true for Canada at least, but the major players in Europe (UK, France) independently saw a benefit to invading Afghanistan. Pakistan‚Äôs involvement with al-Qaeda in particular freaked the hell out of the UK. That‚Äôs why European support dropped off when the US turned to Iraq (not as concerning to Europe), but they still stayed engaged in Pakistan and Afghanistan.
